image.altText: Two people in blue suits walk into a petrol station.

props.synopsis: A 27-year-old has been charged with murder after a 51-year-old man, who was known to him, died at a remote roadhouse on Friday.

title.children: Man charged with murder following remote WA roadhouse death

image.altText: The front façade of a prison at dusk

props.synopsis: Western Australian taxpayers aren't getting bang for their buck in the area of youth justice, but it's children who are paying the highest price.

title.children: Here's why not investing in youth justice is costing taxpayers more and making everyone less safe

image.altText: A man is dwarfed by a large orange tractor statue

props.synopsis: The farming town of Carnamah is making headlines across the globe thanks to a giant new attraction.

title.children: This little WA town has unveiled the next big thing — the world's largest tractor

image.altText: Two men wave at the camera as they walk off a flight in Cyprus

props.synopsis: The first two Australian government charter flights land in the Mediterranean island to help Australian citizens, permanent residents and their family members flee the worsening conflict in Lebanon.

title.children: Relief, but concern for those left behind as Australians land safely in Cyprus

image.altText: A child sits next to a sandy crater

props.synopsis: With the first anniversary of the October 7 attacks on Israel looming, we ask a wide range of experts in the Middle East how the current crisis ends.

title.children: From an ex-Mossad officer to conflict analysts, we ask experts where the Middle East is heading next

image.altText: Scott Portelli smiling from the icy water.

props.synopsis: Scott Portelli built a successful career photographing Antarctica's diverse and unpredictable wildlife. Now, he's moved from Sydney to remote Western Australia to deepen his connection with nature.

title.children: Wildlife photographer Scott Portelli says after decades capturing Antarctica's 'visual feast' he's noticing 'obvious change'

image.altText: debris can be seen on cars in an area of Tripoli sectioned off by police tape

props.synopsis: An Israeli strike hits Lebanon's northern city of Tripoli, killing a Hamas official, after more bombardment in Beirut's suburbs.

title.children: Hamas official killed in Israeli strike on refugee camp in Tripoli

image.altText: A woman smiling holding a virtual reality headset

props.synopsis: The 90s saw a spate of games targeted at girls but they leaned heavily on stereotypes. Now, women are making games that try to represent the breadth of their experiences. And they're on display at Melbourne International Games Week.

title.children: 'You can play as Nicki Minaj in Call of Duty': How games are evolving to embrace feminine perspectives

image.altText: An illustration of a woman walking up a ladder on a snakes and ladders board

props.synopsis: Across Australia, households on six figure incomes are struggling to pay the rent or mortgages – let alone afford little luxuries. Others are delaying retirement or working extra jobs to pay the bills.

title.children: As house prices and inflation bite, is Australia's middle class falling behind?

image.altText: A close up of a bald man wearing a striped shirt standing in his garage.

props.synopsis: Soaring power bills and plunging incentives for excess solar power are pushing more Australian households into installing home energy storage. Yet these batteries are still very expensive and don't stack up for many.

title.children: Calls for federal grants on home batteries as energy retailers slammed for 'un-Australian' solar payment drops

image.altText: Wide show of Ratcliffe coal plant, with fence and coal yard in the foreground and plant and power lines in the background

props.synopsis: More than 150 years after pioneering the technology, the UK has shut its last coal-fired power station. Experts say it's a seminal moment for the energy transition.

title.children: The birthplace of the industrial revolution is done with coal. What does that tell the rest of the world?

image.altText: Beth Mooney plays a shot while batting against Sri Lanka

props.synopsis: Pace star Megan Schutt equals a record and opener Beth Mooney produces a steadying knock as Australia open their T20 World Cup title defence with a six-wicket win over Sri Lanka.

title.children: Mooney to the rescue as Australia beats Sri Lanka in T20 World Cup opener

image.altText: David Speirs in a white shirt at a park with trees

props.synopsis: Former SA opposition leader David Speirs has been charged with two counts of supplying a controlled substance and will face court, police have confirmed.

title.children: Former SA Liberal leader to face court charged with drug offences, police confirm

image.altText: A person in a long sleeved white collared shirt and black pants walks into the Reserve Bank of Australia as its doors slide open

props.synopsis: Australians are increasingly hopeful that cost of living pressures are about to ease, and expect to receive an interest rate cut soon, according to new polling.

title.children: Australians optimistic a rate cut could be on the way as the cost of living crisis bites harder

image.altText: Forensic police officers search through the room of a house and pull up the floorboards.

props.synopsis: NSW Police have charged a woman over the alleged murder and dismemberment of her husband in Sydney's south-west. An investigation was launched into the matter after 62-year-old Mamdouh Noufl was reported missing in July 2023.

title.children: Woman charged over alleged murder and dismemberment of husband in Sydney's south-west

image.altText: Suchita Smith poses for a photo on a tree-lined board walk, wearing a red floral dress and black cardigan

props.synopsis: Suchita Smith was born with a degenerative condition that leads to short stature and badly-formed joints, causing significant chronic pain. But she loves to dance — and as physical limitations have taken hold, she has learnt to find other ways to do it.

title.children: Suchita lives with a painful degenerative condition that means just standing up hurts. It hasn't stopped her dancing

image.altText: An Ecovacs robot on a kitchen floor, and its owner crouching over it

props.synopsis: The ABC has found critical cybersecurity vulnerabilities in Ecovacs devices.

title.children: Insecure Deebot robot vacuums collect photos and audio to train AI

image.altText: A white man in his 60s with long straight hair wearing jeans and a black t-shirt that reads 'unsubscribe'

props.synopsis: The acclaimed West Australian author imagines what life will be like for our descendants if we do nothing about climate change in his much-anticipated latest novel.

title.children: Juice is Tim Winton's first novel in six years. Here's what we thought about it

image.altText: Mid shot of a woman and a man addressing the media.

props.synopsis: Against warnings from health, justice and Aboriginal groups, the NT government says it will fulfil its election promise and return the age of criminal responsibility back to 10 this year.

title.children: 'It's going to scar them': NT to become first jurisdiction to lower criminal age of responsibility

image.altText: Wind turbines are set to dot the landscape in Victoria's west

props.synopsis: Five months after the federal government committed more than $22 billion over 10 years to boost green hydrogen as an alternative fuel, two major projects have hit the skids.

title.children: Why Australia's energy policy continues to be dominated by politics rather than economics

image.altText: Shane Smithers, in a beanie, paints intricate white lines on a large mural

props.synopsis: Shane's been in dozens of caves. He's never seen dots. So why are they the dominant Aboriginal visual language?

title.children: 'We didn't have dots': How Aboriginal visual language became homogenised

image.altText: A solar system on a rooftop at sunset.

props.synopsis: Solar businesses across the country are owed millions of dollars for work they have done as part of Australia's flagship green power scheme. But it's not customers owing them money. It's the middlemen, sitting at the heart of the financial plumbing behind it.

title.children: Billions are sloshing through the solar industry. It has attracted 'cowboys' looking to game the system

image.altText: An upright Lebanese flag being waved through Sydney CBD

props.synopsis: The deteriorating situation in Lebanon has drawn a particular focus in Australia with the widening conflict in the Middle East. But why does Australia have such a large diaspora from a relatively small country on the other side of the world?

title.children: Australia's Lebanese community is largely based in Sydney. Here's why

image.altText: A black and white cow.

props.synopsis: Everything is bigger in Texas, even bird flu amongst cattle. But while there are concerns for Australian dairy farmers they say things are in a state of alert rather than alarm.

title.children: 'Alert but not alarmed': Australian dairy farmers react to fears of deadly strain of bird flu

image.altText: A graphic showing more women than men outside toilets.

props.synopsis: Queuing is never a pleasant experience, especially if you're desperate to go — and while new research has revealed it's an issue that disproportionately affects women, experts say that tweaks to building codes could help reduce the problem.

title.children: Toilet lines are longer for women than men, but simple changes could reduce loo queues

image.altText: A lady smiling for a selfie with a man on a horse behind her waving to the camera

props.synopsis: Being in a relationship doesn't mean you should feel guilty for travelling without your significant other. Here's why it can strengthen your bond.

title.children: 'Couples that do everything together, stay together.' Erin didn't let this stop her from travelling overseas solo

image.altText: Lachlan Morton on the ground after his bike ride.

props.synopsis: Port Macquarie man Lachlan Morton rides into history as the fastest cyclist to travel around mainland Australia.

title.children: Cyclist smashes Around Australia record by seven days in epic 14,201km ride

image.altText: A crime scene with emergency servies pictured on a wet road

props.synopsis: In 2006, a secret recording proved Duc Nguyen was the victim of police brutality. Two decades later, another recording exposed him as a killer.

title.children: After a life plagued by crime, killer Duc Nguyen is jailed for 29 years over Fitzroy shooting

image.altText: Frances Crawford died in July

props.synopsis: The belongings of Frances Crawford, who police say was murdered, were cleared from her home in the weeks after her death, before her husband advertised it on Airbnb.

title.children: 'Murdered' Queensland mum's home pops up on Airbnb as 'absolute bush paradise'

image.altText: an ambulance with lights on outside a two-storey pub at night

props.synopsis: A man has been left with life-threatening injuries after a car was allegedly driven "at speed" into a crowd outside a pub in South Australia at the start of the long weekend, police say.

title.children: Young man fighting for life after car 'reverses' into group outside pub, police say

image.altText: A close-up shot of a bird with a yellow beak and patterned feathers.

props.synopsis: When George Cullinan discovered the plains-wanderer, a small, shy and critically endangered bird with a moo-like call, on his farm in Victoria's Mallee he went about creating a sanctuary to protect it.

title.children: A sanctuary for one of Australia's rarest birds was a 98yo farmer's 'last gift'

image.altText: Liquid chocolate poured from a jug into three moulds in the shape of rabbits

props.synopsis: As chocolate makers ramp up for one of the busiest times of the year, experts are warning of a sharp price increase in the next few months.

title.children: Chocolate lovers told to expect post-Christmas price rise, amid 'cocoa crisis'

image.altText: Harry Grant, with a huge smile, hugs Ryan Papenhuyzen after he scored a try for the Melbourne Storm

props.synopsis: Growing up on the Queensland coast as the youngest of four boys, Harry Grant's parents knew he had enough "mongrel" in him to tackle any challenge on or off the footy field.

title.children: Charting the rise of Harry Grant from surfer kid to NRL grand final captain
